conclusion: Analyze the velocity-time graph to determine collision time.
Graph shows velocities of Car A and Car B as functions of time, both start braking at t = 0, velocities decrease linearly to zero.
At t = 0, Car A's velocity is 25 m/s, Car B's is 15 m/s. At t = 20 s, both have velocity of approximately 5 m/s.
Before t = 20 s, Car A is faster than Car B, reducing the distance between them.
After t = 20 s, both cars have the same velocity, maintaining constant distance if no collision.
Collision occurs if Car A catches up to Car B while both are moving.
If Car A catches up before t = 20 s, collision happens before 20 seconds.
If Car A does not catch up by t = 20 s, collision cannot happen afterward.
Slope of lines represents deceleration; Car A's slope is steeper than Car B's.
Car A's greater deceleration means it closes the gap more quickly initially.
Car A will catch up to Car B before t = 20 s due to faster initial speed and greater deceleration.
Intersection of lines before t = 20 s indicates collision time.
The two cars collide before 20 seconds of braking.
